question: In the interlaced optical force‐fluorescence (IOFF) setup described by Brau et al. in Biophysical Journal 91(3) (pages 1069–1077), what is the characteristic decay constant (i.e. the measured lifetime) of single Cy3 fluorophores under the out‐of‐phase (OP) modulation condition?

evidence.fact: The paper by Brau et al. shows that Cy3 dyes, when exposed to the OP modulation configuration, exhibit a decay constant of 32.03 ± 5.72 seconds, compared to only 1.49 ± 0.10 seconds under the in-phase condition—demonstrating roughly a 20‐fold improvement in fluorophore longevity.

According to the detailed experimental results in the Biophysical Journal paper (Brau et al., 2006), the out-of-phase modulated condition extends the lifetime of single Cy3 fluorophores to around 32 seconds.

question: What is the name of the traditional Florentine sport, dating back to the 16th century, that is played in a sand-filled arena with two teams of 27 players each?

evidence.fact: Calcio Storico, originating in Florence, Italy, is a sport that blends elements of soccer, rugby, and wrestling. Dating back to the 16th century, it is played in a sand-filled arena with two teams of 27 players each, making it a distinctive and historically rich athletic contest.

Calcio Storico, also known as historical football, is a traditional sport from Florence that emerged in the 16th century. It features two teams of 27 players competing in a sand-filled arena, with gameplay that incorporates elements of soccer, rugby, and wrestling.

question: What is the elevation above sea level of the geographic center of the Netherlands located at the Centre Spot in Lunteren?

evidence.fact: This page explains that the geographic center of the Netherlands is hidden in the woods near Lunteren on the Veluwe, with a marked location on a hill (the Koepol or Lindeboomsberg) that lies at 51 meters above sea level.

question: In the leaked Signal group chat from March 2025 that involved high‐ranking national security officials discussing imminent military operations against Yemen’s Houthi forces, what was the official name of the group chat?

evidence.fact: Jeffrey Goldberg’s reporting in The Atlantic detailed that National Security Advisor Michael Waltz created a private Signal group chat and, on March 13, mistakenly added Goldberg to it. The chat was labeled 'Houthi PC small group' and was used to coordinate sensitive war plans against the Houthis in Yemen.

Politiico’s coverage of the leak confirmed that the group chat used by senior Trump administration officials to discuss the planned Yemen strikes was named 'Houthi PC small group,' a detail that emerged only after in‐depth investigation of the leaked texts.

question: According to CMAS Underwater Hockey rules version 7.11, what is the minimum age for participants in the National Women Masters teams division for a World Championship?

evidence.fact: 0.2.2 A WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP is a tournament between nations involving one or more of the following: ... 0.2.2.4 A minimum of three (3) National Women Masters teams aged 32 years or more. A woman master must have attained her 32nd birthday on or before the first game of the competition.

1.3.2 Divisions ... 1.3.2.4 Women’s Master’s Division. Minimum age is 32. There is no upper age limit. Players age to be determined as per Rule 1.3.1. ... 1.4 Age Exceptions ... 1.4.2 The Women’s Master’s Division for World Championship of 2020 will have the minimum age of 32, just in the world championships after the minimum age will be 34.

question: What is the maximum integer number of blocks a player can fall in Minecraft without enchantments or effects and survive (assuming full health)?

evidence.fact: To calculate fall damage with no Armour, it is quite simply. Just obtain the amount of blocks high you are, and then minus 3... For example at 22 and 23 blocks high, the same damage value of 19 is generated. However at 24 blocks high, 21 hearts [damage points/half-hearts] of damage is generated... Therefore it can be confirmed 23 blocks is the largest amount of blocks high, one with only armour/no armour/ blocking can survive from.

Generally, the way fall damage works is that you lose half of the heart of health for every block fallen after you pass the first three blocks. Assuming that you have a full health bar while falling, a fall should prove to be lethal once it exceeds 23 blocks (or 23.5 to be more exact).

question: In which 1988 TV movie featuring a prominent Marvel character did the recurring dual generator prop (Modern Props #2571) notably appear?

evidence.fact: This prop has been used in many Sci-Fi projects including Star Trek, The Incredible Hulk Returns (1988 TV movie), V (the old one), The Last Starfighter, Buck Rogers and oddly enough in AIRPLANE II: The Sequel with William Shatner who would again encounter it in Star Trek V: The Final Frontier which William Shatner directed and starred in! ... "Modern Props designed and fabricated dual medical / lab / control room generator with rotating neon lights inside an acrylic tube; light-controlled panel with knobs and buttons." (It can be rented from ModernProps.com for $775 for the first week, in case you want to be in on the joke.)

question: The cover art for Amon Düül II's Yeti album features a photograph of which deceased sound man associated with the band?

evidence.fact: The cover was designed by the band's organist, Falk Rogner, and features a collage depicting the Grim Reaper (German: Der Sensenmann), made from a photograph of Wolfgang Krischke. Krischke, who had worked with the band as a sound man, had died of hypothermia while under the effects of LSD. Rogner said: "When he died I thought that the photo would be a perfect tribute to his memory. He never managed to find his way into Amon Düül properly when he was alive, so maybe his image as 'Der Sensenmann' will work as a strange cover image and he could be remembered as a magical person."

About the cover art, the man in a dress with a scythe is a sound engineer of the band, Wolfgang Krischke. A few months after he was photographed, he died due to a LSD overdose. The German krautrockers paid him tribute by putting his picture on the cover. (Excerpt from user review section on page)

question: During the Roman Tetrarchy, Emperor Diocletian associated himself with Jupiter by taking the cognomen Jovius. Which mythological hero did his co-Augustus, Maximian, associate himself with through his cognomen?

evidence.fact: Diocletian, as senior emperor, associated himself with Jupiter, king of the gods, adopting the name Iovius; Maximian, ever the soldier, identified with the hero Hercules, taking the name Herculius.

Diocletian ruled the East, and Maximian controlled the West. To legitimize their rule and create divine protectors, Maximian took the cognomen Herculius (signifying descent from Hercules) and Diocletian took that of Jovius (signifying descent from Jupiter).

question: What specific early plastic, derived from milk protein, did László Moholy-Nagy incorporate into his kinetic sculpture 'Light Prop for an Electric Stage' (Lichtrequisit einer elektrischen Bühne)?

evidence.fact: The original Light Prop, created between 1922 and 1930, was constructed from a variety of industrial materials including polished aluminum, steel, nickel-plated brass, glass, and plastic (specifically, Galalith and Trolitan). It featured an electric motor that drove the complex movements of its perforated discs, spirals, and rotating glass elements, casting intricate patterns of light and shadow.

Materials: Metal (partly nickel-plated and polished), glass and plastic (Galalith, Trolitan), wood base plate, electric motor, light bulbs. Moholy-Nagy’s Light-Space Modulator, which he began working on in 1922, is a key work of kinetic art.

question: What specific chemical process causes the degradation and notable color loss of smalt pigment, particularly evident in some historical oil paintings like those by Rembrandt?

evidence.fact: Smalt is a moderately permanent pigment with a tendency to fade and turn greyish or yellowish with time especially in oil medium. This degradation is caused by the leaching of potassium ions from the glass matrix. [...] A prominent example of the discoloration of smalt can be seen in the background drapery of the Portrait of Hendrickje Stoffels by Rembrandt van Rijn in the National Gallery in London.

The blue pigment smalt (ground cobalt-containing potash glass) is known to discolour in oil medium as a result of potassium leaching from the glass particles. The degraded smalt appears greyish or brownish yellow and has very little colouring strength.

question: What specific chemical process causes the degradation and notable color loss of a ground blue pigment made from potassium glass containing cobalt oxide, popular between the 15th and 18th centuries, particularly evident in some historical oil paintings like those by Rembrandt?
parent_question: What specific chemical process causes the degradation and notable color loss of smalt pigment, particularly evident in some historical oil paintings like those by Rembrandt?

evidence.fact: Smalt is a moderately permanent pigment with a tendency to fade and turn greyish or yellowish with time especially in oil medium. This degradation is caused by the leaching of potassium ions from the glass matrix. [...] A prominent example of the discoloration of smalt can be seen in the background drapery of the Portrait of Hendrickje Stoffels by Rembrandt van Rijn in the National Gallery in London.

The blue pigment smalt (ground cobalt-containing potash glass) is known to discolour in oil medium as a result of potassium leaching from the glass particles. The degraded smalt appears greyish or brownish yellow and has very little colouring strength.

Smalt is a ground blue potassium glass containing cobalt. It is made by melting cobalt oxide together with potash and silica, quenching the molten glass in water, and grinding the resulting shards. Smalt has been identified on paintings dating from the fifteenth through the eighteenth centuries.
Smalt is essentially potassium glass coloured blue with cobalt oxide. Its use as a pigment spans from the 15th to the 18th century.

question: What specific chemical process causes the degradation and notable color loss of a historically significant blue pigment, known for being a coarsely ground glass popular with Old Masters like Rembrandt between the 15th and 18th centuries, which often contained cobalt, sometimes acted as a siccative, but exhibited notable instability and discoloration when used in oil binders?
parent_question: What specific chemical process causes the degradation and notable color loss of a ground blue pigment made from potassium glass containing cobalt oxide, popular between the 15th and 18th centuries, particularly evident in some historical oil paintings like those by Rembrandt?

evidence.fact: Smalt is a moderately permanent pigment with a tendency to fade and turn greyish or yellowish with time especially in oil medium. This degradation is caused by the leaching of potassium ions from the glass matrix. [...] A prominent example of the discoloration of smalt can be seen in the background drapery of the Portrait of Hendrickje Stoffels by Rembrandt van Rijn in the National Gallery in London.

The blue pigment smalt (ground cobalt-containing potash glass) is known to discolour in oil medium as a result of potassium leaching from the glass particles. The degraded smalt appears greyish or brownish yellow and has very little colouring strength.

Smalt is a ground blue potassium glass containing cobalt. It is made by melting cobalt oxide together with potash and silica, quenching the molten glass in water, and grinding the resulting shards. Smalt has been identified on paintings dating from the fifteenth through the eighteenth centuries.
Smalt is essentially potassium glass coloured blue with cobalt oxide. Its use as a pigment spans from the 15th to the 18th century.

Smalt is a pigment made of ground blue potassium glass containing cobalt... It was widely used in European painting between the 15th and 18th centuries... Smalt is known for its tendency to lose its color over time, especially when used in oil medium... The discoloration is caused by the leaching of potassium ions from the glass matrix... Cobalt as a component of smalt also acts as a siccative... Notable painters who employed smalt include Titian, Tintoretto, Veronese, Rembrandt, Vermeer, Velázquez, Murillo, Rubens, Jordaens, Brueghel, Claude Lorrain and Poussin.

Smalt is a ground potash glass containing cobalt oxide... Due to its low refractive index, it has low hiding power in oil medium... Smalt tends to discolor in oil medium... The cobalt in smalt is a powerful drier (siccative) of linseed oil and was sometimes added to paint mixtures solely for this purpose.

question: What specific chemical process causes the degradation and notable color loss when used in oil binders of a certain blue pigment characterized by the following? 1) It is a man-made vitreous pigment. 2) Its production involves melting sand, potash, and cobalt oxide. 3) Its use declined significantly following the discovery of a synthetic blue pigment by Louis Jacques Thénard in the early 19th century.

Cobalt as a component of smalt also acts as a siccative... The cobalt in smalt is a powerful drier (siccative) of linseed oil and was sometimes added to paint mixtures solely for this purpose.
Smalt is described as a man-made (artificially prepared) vitreous pigment (ground blue cobalt-containing potassium glass).
The production of Smalt involves melting cobalt oxide together with quartz (sand) and potash.
Cobalt blue, a synthetic blue pigment, was discovered by Louis Jacques Thénard in 1802.
The use and production of smalt declined sharply in the 19th century due to the availability of newer blue pigments like cobalt blue (discovered by Thénard) and artificial ultramarine.

Smalt, blue pigment produced by grinding cobalt-containing glass to a fine powder. Smalt is made by fusing potash, silica sand, and cobalt oxide; the molten glass is poured into water, shattered, and ground.

Cobalt blue in impure forms had long been used in Chinese porcelain, but it was discovered as a pure alumina-based pigment by Louis Jacques Thénard in 1802. Its discovery led to the decline in the use of smalt.

question: Which specific type of artillery piece, known for its effectiveness against fortifications, did Mehmed II use extensively during the Siege of Constantinople in 1453, as documented in contemporary accounts?

evidence.fact: The Orban bombard or Basilica was a supergun designed by Orban, a cannon founder from Brassó, Kingdom of Hungary (now Brașov, Romania), who offered his services to the Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II in 1452, the year before the Fall of Constantinople. Orban was one of at least two cannon founders offering their services to the sultan; the other founder, Munir Ali, produced the majority of the cannons used by the Ottomans in the siege. However, the Orban bombard was the largest cannon possessed by either side, and according to most historical accounts, it was this weapon that battered down the Theodosian Walls, leading to the capture of the city.

Mehmed II's army included a number of very large cannons, the most famous of which was the 'Basilica' or Great Turkish Bombard, designed by a Hungarian engineer named Orban. This massive bronze cannon, reportedly over 27 feet (8 meters) long, could fire stone balls weighing upwards of 1,200 pounds (540 kg) over a mile. While slow to reload and prone to cracking, its psychological impact and destructive power against the ancient walls were significant factors in the siege.

question: According to contemporary accounts of the Siege of Constantinople in 1453, which specific type of artillery piece, known for its effectiveness against fortifications, was extensively used by the Ottoman Sultan famous for ordering his warships dragged overland into the Golden Horn?

evidence.fact: The Orban bombard or Basilica was a supergun designed by Orban, a cannon founder from Brassó, Kingdom of Hungary (now Brașov, Romania), who offered his services to the Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II in 1452, the year before the Fall of Constantinople. This massive bronze cannon, reportedly over 27 feet (8 meters) long, could fire stone balls weighing upwards of 1,200 pounds (540 kg) over a mile. While slow to reload and prone to cracking, its psychological impact and destructive power against the ancient walls were significant factors in the siege.
One of Mehmet II's most famous tactics during the siege [of Constantinople in 1453] was the transportation of seventy Ottoman ships overland from the Bosphorus into the Golden Horn.
During the Siege of Constantinople (1453), on April 22 Mehmet [II] ordered his lighter warships dragged overland from the Bosphorus to the Golden Horn on wooden rollers.

question: According to contemporary accounts of the Siege of Constantinople in 1453, which specific type of artillery piece, known for its effectiveness against fortifications, was extensively used by the Ottoman Sultan who first ascended the throne in 1444 at the age of 12, abdicated two years later in favour of his father, and regained power permanently in 1451?

Mehmed II (born March 30, 1432) first ruled as Ottoman sultan from 1444 (at age 12) to 1446.
During his first reign, Mehmed II was pressured to abdicate in favour of his father, Murad II, in 1446, before succeeding his father permanently upon Murad II's death in 1451.

question: During the pivotal military engagement that concluded on May 29, 1453, leading to the demise of the final Byzantine Emperor and the dissolution of the Eastern Roman Empire, contemporary accounts mention the extensive use of a specific type of fortification-breaching artillery. This artillery was employed by a historical ruler notable for: 1) reported fluency in multiple languages including Greek and Latin, and 2) the promulgation of new regulations compiled into a Kanun-name (Book of Laws). What was this specific type of artillery piece?

evidence.fact: The Orban bombard or Basilica was a supergun designed by Orban, a cannon founder from Brassó, Kingdom of Hungary (now Brașov, Romania), who offered his services to the Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II in 1452, the year before the Fall of Constantinople. During his first reign, Mehmed II was pressured to abdicate in favour of his father, Murad II, in 1446, before succeeding his father permanently upon Murad II's death in 1451.
Mehmed II was a cultured and learned man who was fluent in several languages, including Turkish, Arabic, Persian, Hebrew, Serbian, Greek, and Latin.
He [Mehmed II] promulgated a series of new regulations and laws, compiled into a Kanun-name (Book of Laws).

The Fall of Constantinople occurred on May 29, 1453, after a siege which began on April 6. The capture of the city... marked the end of the Byzantine Empire, a continuation of the Roman Empire under its emperor Constantine XI Palaiologos.

The city fell on 29 May 1453 CE... The consequence of the Fall of Constantinople was, then, the end of the Byzantine Empire which had survived for over a millennium and the final demise of the Roman Empire founded by Augustus in 27 BCE.

question: During the pivotal military engagement concluded on the day Constantine XI Palaiologos died, leading to the dissolution of the Eastern Roman Empire, contemporary accounts mention the extensive use of a specific type of fortification-breaching artillery. In 1479 the Venetian painter Gentile Bellini was sent to Constantinople (by then Istanbul) at the request of Sultan Mehmet II (also known as Mehmed II) to paint his portrait.
Constantine XI Palaeologus, the last Byzantine emperor, died defending Constantinople during its fall on May 29, 1453.

question: Which specific administrative subprefecture of Tokyo Metropolis governs both the island group that includes Iwo Jima and Japan's easternmost point?

evidence.fact: Ogasawara Subprefecture (小笠原支庁, Ogasawara-shichō) is a subprefecture of Tokyo Metropolis, Japan. ... Besides the Ogasawara Archipelago, the subprefecture includes other outlying islands such as the Volcano Islands [includes Iwo Jima], Nishinoshima, Minami-Tori-shima [Japan's easternmost point] and Oki-no-Tori-shima [Japan's southernmost point].

The Bonin Islands, also called Ogasawara Islands... administratively part of Tokyo metropolis (to)... They consist of three main groups: the Chichijima Retto (Beechey Islands), the Hahajima Retto (Baily Islands), and the Mukojima Retto (Parry Islands). Geographically associated with the Bonins are the Volcano Islands (Kazan Retto) to the south—which include Iwo Jima—and the isolated islands of Nishino, Minami Tori, and Okinotori. Minami Tori Island (Marcus Island) is the easternmost territory of Japan.

question: In 'Monster Hunter World: Iceborne', on which specific large herbivore species, found exclusively in the Hoarfrost Reach, can the rare endemic life 'Downy Crake' sometimes be found riding?

evidence.fact: Downy Crakes are rare birds that have a small chance of appearing on the backs of Aptonoth, Apceros, or Popo in various locales. [...] They are small white birds that flock together on the backs of herbivores.

Popo are large, woolly herbivores resembling mammoths, introduced in Monster Hunter 2 and reappearing in Monster Hunter World: Iceborne. They are exclusively found grazing in herds within the Hoarfrost Reach.
